trial_identification.studytitle: Insulin-sensitive Obesity: Lessons From Longitudinal Data
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Insulin-sensitive Obesity: Prospective and Interventional Studies

interventions.interventions:
Other interventions - Longitudinal study
Experimental: Longitudinal follow up - Participant's metabolic parameters are followed up after approximately 6 years.
Other interventions: Longitudinal study Metabolic health, anthropometry, body fat distribution, liver lipid will be followed up in individuals previously studied at the Clinical Research Facility.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in insulin sensitivity - Insulin sensitivity will be assessed in this current follow up study. This will be compared to insulin sensitivity data collected in this study cohort approximately 6 years ago.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: change in insulin sensitivity at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in anthropometry (weight, height, BMI, waist and hip circumference)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in total body fat and distribution
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in fasting insulin, c-peptide, glucose levels
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in HbA1c, 75g oral glucose tolerance
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in fasting non-esterified fatty acids and lipids profile
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in circulating adipokines, cytokines and hepatokines
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago
Change at follow up compared to 6 years ago

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Participation in the previous SiDIRAD (1) or EXCESS (2-6) study.
- Willingness to give written informed consent and willingness to participate in and comply with the study.

recruitment.hospital: Garvan Institute of Medical Research - Darlinghurst

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: Baker IDI Heart and Diabetes Institute

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
People who are overweight and/or obese usually are insulin resistant and so are at risk of type 2 diabetes. However, research has shown that some overweight and/or obese people remain insulin sensitive and healthy despite their weight.
The investigators hypothesise that insulin-sensitive overweight and/or obese people maintain their insulin sensitivity and metabolic health over time. The investigators also hypothesise that the preservation of insulin sensitivity will be determined by key metabolic factors.
